Papers: Combining active inference and hierarchical predictive coding: a tutorial introduction and case study
Contrastive active inference
Notes: One particular challenge with such discrete state-space active inference models is the fact that it is difficult to scale the model to a large number of states and quickly becomes computationally expensive. In Chapter 13 we described \textit{contrastive active inference} \citep{Mazzaglia2021-oj} a possible approach to more effecient discrete-state space active inference-based control using contrastive learning. The authors in this paper argue that since complete pixel-level visual reconstruction is expensive and may be unnecessary for many tasks, the model's complexity can be reduced if it selectively choose which observations are relevant for the decision-making task at hand. After augmenting VFE and EFE with a contrastive loss term, the model better identifies similar observations that were likely generate by the hidden state to be inferred.

Notes: Drawback: AIC biased toward current goal prior (poor state estimation). Influences precision learning by biasing parameter convergence. False-positive fault detection. Control action not an random variable. Thus cannot minimize directly and must use the chain rule (assumes system is linear).

Papers: Variational Inference for Predictive and Reactive Controllers
Notes: The authors interpret the work in \citep{Oliver2019-uo, Pezzato2019-mx} in terms of \textit{reactive control}. They point out the fact that because continuous state-space active inference can only adaptively react to prediction errors it will have a much slower response. By separating the state-estimation and action steps the model can run them in parallel and adapt faster to environmental changes. Reactive control. Re-read this paper in more detail. It's kind of a robotics paper but really they introduce a few modifications to generalized filtering.
